Graphical abstract With renewable cycloketone, benzaldehyde, and isoprene as feedstocks, an efficient three-step catalytic route is developed for the production of advanced C17 and C18 spiro-fuel. High-energy-density (HED) fuel (e.g. widely used JP-10 and RJ-4), featuring compact 3D polycyclic structure with high strain, is of critical importance for volume-limited military aircraft, since their high density and combustion heat can provide more propulsion energy. To reduce the reliance on petroleum source, it is highly desirable to develop renewable alternatives for the production of strained polycyclic HED fuel, but which remains a big challenge because of the inaccessibility caused by the high strain. We herein demonstrate a three-step catalytic route towards highly strained C17 and C18 spirofuel with biomass feedstocks. The process includes catalytic aldol condensation of renewable cyclohexanone/cyclopentanone with benzaldehyde, catalytic spiro Diels-Alder (D-A) reaction of aldol adduct with isoprene, and catalytic hydrodeoxygenation. The key spiro D-A reaction is enabled by the catalysis of heterogeneous Lewis acidic ionic liquid. The chloroaluminate IL, formed by benign urea and AlCl3, exhibits good catalytic performance and reusability for this step. An eventual hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) over Pd/C and H-Y produces strained tricyclic spirofuel with density >0.93 g/mL, combustion heat >41 MJ/L and freezing point < −40 °C, which are better than the properties of tactical fuel RJ-4. Therefore, it is anticipated that the as-prepared renewable fuels have the potential to replace traditional petroleum-derived HED fuels. Keywords Biomass derivatives High-energy-density Spiro polycyclic fuel Cycloaddition Lewis acidic ionic liquid Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Jet fuel is a special type of fuel (C9–C20 hydrocarbons) used to power jet engines. Particularly, for the military aircraft with volume-limited oil tank such as fighters, bombers, rockets and missiles, the energy density of jet fuel plays a pivotal role in improving their flight range and payload [1]. Therefore, the development and synthesis of high-energy-density (HED) fuel is of critical importance in safeguarding territorial air security. Compared with conventional kerosene Jet-A (density 0.78 g/mL, combustion heat 33.2 MJ/L), HED fuel generally consists of unique polycyclic hydrocarbons with density > 0.85 g/mL and combustion heat >38 MJ/L. The ring opening of polycycloalkanes can generate extra energy during combustion, thus leading to higher energy density. As shown in Table 1 , the extensively used HED fuels JP-10, RJ-4 and RJ-5 all possess bridged and fused polycycloalkanes, which are prepared from petroleum-based cyclopentadiene, methylcyclopentadiene, and norbornadiene via a three-step process involving cycloaddition, hydrogenation and isomerization [2]. To reduce the reliance on non-renewable petroleum source and achieve carbon neutrality in aviation industry [3–5], biomass valorization into HED fuels has become a fascinating research hotspot in recent years. The groups of Harvey [6–9], Zou [10–14], Ma [15–18], Li [19–25] and others [26–30] have made great contributions to this field. Most of the precedents focus on the synthesis of simple unstrained polycyclic HED fuels with biomass-based platform molecules. Nevertheless, from the chemical structures of typical high-performance fuels (Table 1), we can see that besides the inherent multiple carbocycles, the compact 3D structure also gives rise to high strain-energy, which can further increase the energy density via strain release during combustion. By mimicking this structural characteristic, it is much more appealing to exploit renewable alternatives for producing strained polycyclic HED fuel [31–34]. Benzaldehyde is an important aromatic aldehyde that can be prepared by C–C bond cleavage of lignin models or alkaline hydrolysis of renewable cinnamaldehyde [35,36]. Cyclohexanone can be made via selective hydrogenation of lignin-based aromatic ethers over modified Pd/C catalyst [37]. Cyclopentanone is another renewable ketone that can be largely manufactured by hydrogenation/rearrangement of hemicellulose derivative furfural [38,39]. Isoprene is a bulk conjugated diene that can be alternatively attained via fermentation of sugars [40]. With these renewable feedstocks, we herein develop an efficient three-step catalytic route for the production of advanced C17 and C18 spiro-fuel (Fig. 1 ) [41–44]. Benzaldehyde first reacts with cyclohexanone/cyclopentanone very easily under basic conditions. The resulting aldol products further undergo spiro Diels-Alder (D-A) reaction with isoprene smoothly at room temperature in the presence of Lewis acidic ionic liquid (IL) catalyst. The chloroaluminate IL, formed by urea and AlCl3, displays high catalytic performance and good reusability for this step. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report on unique spiro D-A reaction enabled by the catalysis of Lewis acidic ionic liquid (IL). Finally, hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) over a physical mixture of Pd/C and H-Y results in the formation of jet-fuel-range polycycloalkanes 3 and 6. The highly-strained spiro-type tricyclic ring structure leads to high density (>0.93 g/mL) and volumetric net heat of combustion (VNHOC, > 41 MJ/L), as well as low freezing point (< −40 oC), which are better than the properties of advanced fuel RJ-4. Thus, it is anticipated that the as-prepared renewable fuels have the potential to replace traditional petroleum-derived HED fuels. We demonstrate these promising results in details. 2 Experimental 2.1 General information Benzaldehyde, tridecane, naphthalene, AlCl3 and urea were provided by Aladdin Industrial Corporation. Cyclohexanone, cyclopentanone and isoprene were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. [Emim]Cl, [Bmim]Cl, FeCl3, Fe(OTf)3, Al(OTf)3 and Sc(OTf)3 were obtained from Leyan Company. KOH and NaOH were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. The commonly used solvents including propylene carbonate (PC), dichloromethane (DCM), acetonitrile, ethyl acetate, toluene, cyclohexane and diethyl ether were supplied by Xilong Scientific Co., Ltd. All chemicals were of analytical grade and were used without further purification. The Pd/C, Pt/C, Ru/C, and Rh/C catalysts were obtained from Shanghai Titan Scientific Co., ltd. To facilitate the comparison, the metal contents in these catalysts were chosen as 5% by weight. NMR spectra were recorded at room temperature in CDCl3 on 600 MHz spectrometers. The chemical shifts for 1H NMR were recorded in ppm downfield using the peak of CDCl3 (7.26 ppm) as the internal standard. The chemical shifts for 13C NMR were recorded in ppm downfield using the central peak of CDCl3 (77.16 ppm) as the internal standard. FT-IR spectra were recorded using a Nicolet iS5 FT-IR spectrometer. Solid samples were prepared by pressing potassium bromide powder (KBr) into tablets, and liquid samples were prepared by smearing on KBr tablets with a scanning range of 4000–400 cm−1. Thermogravimetric (TG) data were acquired using a Netzsch thermal analyzer model STA 449F5 under the following conditions: N2 atmosphere, temperature increase rate of 10 °C min−1, starting temperature of 35 °C and termination temperature of 500 °C. The density of spirofuel was measured by an Anton Paar SY-05 digital densitometer. Freezing point was measured by a Dalian Intelligent DZY-041 freezing point detector. The volumetric net heat of combustion (VNHOC) was measured by a Dalian Intelligent DZY-R1B calorimeter. Each measurement was performed for three times. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Lewis acid AlCl3 (2.667 g, 20 mmol) and [Emim]Cl (1.47 g, 10 mmol) were added to a sealed tube (35 mL) in sequence. The mixture was stirred at 80 °C for 20 min until the solids were dissolved to form a homogeneous solution. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting solution was Lewis acidic ionic liquid [Emim]Cl/AlCl3 catalyst. Lewis acid AlCl3 (2.667 g, 20 mmol) and [Bmim]Cl (1.75 g, 10 mmol) were added to a sealed tube (35 mL) in sequence. The mixture was stirred at 80 °C for 20 min until the solids were dissolved to form a homogeneous solution. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting solution was Lewis acidic ionic liquid [Bmim]Cl/AlCl3 catalyst. Lewis acid AlCl3 (2.0 g, 15 mmol) and urea (0.6 g, 10 mmol) were added to a sealed tube (35 mL) in sequence. The mixture was stirred at 120 °C for 20 min until the solids were dissolved to form a homogeneous solution. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting solution was Lewis acidic ionic liquid urea/AlCl3 catalyst. 2.3 Catalytic aldol condensation of benzaldehyde and cyclohexanone To a mixture of benzaldehyde (0.1 mL, 1 mmol) and cyclohexanone (0.15 mL, 1.5 mmol) was added 1 N KOH solution (1 mL) or ionic liquid ethanolamine/acetic acid (10 mol%). The resulting solution was stirred at 90 °C for 3 h. Upon completion, the mixture spontaneously separated into two phases. The organic phase was diluted with ethyl acetate and analyzed by Fuli GC F80 equipped with KB-1 column (30 m, 0.32 mm ID, 0.5 μm film) and a flame ionization detector (FID) using tridecane as the internal standard. 2.4 Catalytic spiro D-A reaction of isoprene and aldol adduct In a sealed tube (35 mL), isoprene (0.5 mL, 5 mmol), aldol adduct 1 (0.3725 g, 2.0 mmol), toluene (2.0 mL) and urea/AlCl3 (molar ratio 1:1.5, 52 mg) were added in sequence. The system was stirred at room temperature for 0.5 h. Upon completion, the product (upper layer) was separated by decantation. As ILs urea/AlCl3 could not be dissolved in toluene, a simple dilution with toluene and subsequent decantation of the upper layer could remove the unreacted residues in the system. The recovered ILs urea/AlCl3 could be used for the next cycle. The yield was determined by Fuli GC F80 equipped with KB-1 column (30 m, 0.32 mm ID, 0.5 μm film) and a flame ionization detector (FID) using naphthalene as the internal standard. 2.5 Catalytic hydrodeoxygenation of spiro D-A adduct In a 50 mL autoclave reactor, the spiro D-A adduct 2 (0.254 g, 1 mmol) was introduced, followed by Pd/C (50.9 mg), H-Y (50.9 mg), and cyclohexane (2.0 mL). The reaction was stirred at 160 °C under 3.5 MPa of hydrogen for 10 h. After cooling down to room temperature, the yield was determined by Fuli GC F80 equipped with KB-1 column (30 m, 0.32 mm ID, 0.5 μm film) and a flame ionization detector (FID) using tridecane as the internal standard. To fulfill the need of practical application, we also checked the reusability of Pd/C and H-Y for the reaction. After each use, the catalysts were centrifuged and thoroughly washed with methanol for the next cycle. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Lewis acid catalyzed spiro D-A reaction of aldol product with isoprene According to our previous work [45], with the aid of renewable and recyclable ionic liquid formed by ethanolamine and acetic acid, biomass-derived cyclohexanone and benzaldehyde efficiently underwent condensation under solvent-free conditions to afford aldol product 1 (Fig. 2 ). Alternatively, the transformation could occur steadily as well in the presence of aqueous potassium hydroxide solution. With the resulting aldol product in hand, we then examined its spiro D-A reaction with isoprene. It is well-known that Lewis acid can activate α,β-unsaturated carbonyl compounds via coordination, thereby lowering the energy gap between highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) of diene and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) of dienophile to facilitate the D-A reaction. Thus, a series of Lewis acids were first screened for promoting the spiro D-A reaction (Fig. 2a). Subjecting Lewis acid FeCl3 to a mixture of aldol product 1 and isoprene in toluene at room temperature gave rise to the desired spiro D-A adduct 2 in 55% yield. A comparable result was achieved in the presence of Fe(OTf)3. To our delight, stronger Lewis acid AlCl3 exhibited excellent catalytic performance towards D-A reaction and the target adduct 2 was attained in 91% yield. By contrast, when varying to Al(OTf)3 and Sc(OTf)3, decreased yields were afforded, which can be ascribed to their lower Lewis acidity than AlCl3 [46,47]. Solid acid resin Amberlyst-15 could barely catalyze the D-A reaction because of a lack of Lewis acid sites. Heterogeneous Lewis acid zeolites such as Sn-Beta and Al-MCM-41, due to their moderate Lewis acidity, could not promote the transformation. Furthermore, it is noteworthy that the reaction did not take place in the absence of catalyst, re-affirming that AlCl3 is crucial for the high efficiency of spiro D-A reaction. The nature of solvents also exerted an evident impact on the reaction outcome (Fig. 2b). The efficiency decreased dramatically when the transformation was conducted in acetonitrile (MeCN) and ethyl acetate (EtOAc). It is because the potential coordination between AlCl3 and solvent can reduce its Lewis acidity. The process was nearly prohibited in cyclohexane (CyH), owing to the poor solubility of starting materials and catalyst. Besides toluene, both dichloromethane (DCM) and propylene carbonate (PC) also led to the formation of the target product in high yields. However, considering the toxicity of dichloromethane and the cost of propylene carbonate, toluene was chosen as the optimal reaction medium. As shown in Fig. 2c, the D-A reaction could be completed within one hour and the yield still maintained around 95% at elevated temperatures. From an economical point of view, room temperature was much better for the process. In addition, when the amount of isoprene and toluene was decreased to 2.4 equivalent and 0.5 mL respectively, a comparable yield of D-A adduct was acquired. 3.2 Catalytic spiro D-A reaction over heterogeneous AlCl3-based ILs While highly efficient, homogeneous catalyst AlCl3 cannot be reused for spiro D-A reaction, which is disadvantageous in practical applications. Ionic liquids (ILs) possess strong electrostatic force and hydrogen-bonding interactions, which render ILs good thermal stability, high polarity, and low miscibility in organic solvents [48]. Of particular note is that AlCl3-based ILs have been widely used as electrolytes in batteries [49], but their applications in catalysis received less attention. As a consequence, additional efforts were devoted to the development of AlCl3-derived ILs, which might simultaneously show good catalytic activity and recyclability. By stirring a mixture of 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride ([Emim]Cl) and AlCl3 (2.0 equivalent of [Emim]Cl) at 80 °C for 20 min, a viscous chloroaluminate liquid was afforded. With this IL [Emim]Cl/AlCl3 as catalyst, the expected spiro D-A adduct 2 was produced in 94% yield (Fig. 2d) and notably, [Emim]Cl/AlCl3 remained immiscible with the system during the reaction. Lewis acidic IL, formed by 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride ([Bmim]Cl) and AlCl3, was a suitable catalyst as well and the yield of 2 was slightly enhanced. Deep eutectic solvents (DESs) are a special class of ILs formed by mixing hydrogen-bond acceptors (HBAs) and hydrogen-bond donors (HBDs) [50]. Urea is a common hydrogen-bond donor which can interact with AlCl3 (1.5 equivalent of urea) to generate a Lewis acidic DES. In the presence of urea/AlCl3, the spiro D-A reaction occurred readily and a comparable result was achieved. Over Lewis acidic DESs formed by acetamide/caprolactam with AlCl3, the desired D-A adduct 2 was afforded in a high yield as well. Given the biodegradability and easy availability of urea, DES catalyst urea/AlCl3 was more preferred in practical applications. It should be mentioned that the amount of isoprene could be decreased to 1.0 equivalent and the yield still remained comparable. The reusability of Lewis acidic ILs for spiro D-A reaction was further examined. Owing to the high viscosity and polarity of ILs, the catalyst was immiscible with toluene and a biphasic system was formed during the reaction [51]. After each usage, the upper layer, consisting of D-A adduct and toluene, was easily isolated by decantation. The lower catalyst layer was recycled for next spiro D-A reaction. As depicted in Fig. 3 a, the Lewis acidic IL [Bmim]Cl/AlCl3 showed a decline in the catalytic performance after three runs. Due to the hygroscopic nature of [Bmim]Cl/AlCl3, the adsorbed water likely reacted with AlCl3 to form hydrogen chloride and the resulting decreased Lewis acidity led to a moderate catalytic efficiency. By comparison, the urea/AlCl3 catalyst can be reused for at least four runs with no evident loss in activity (Fig. 3b). 3.3 Interaction of AlCl3-based ILs To illustrate the interaction of two components in ILs, some characterizations were performed. Fig. 4 a presents the thermogravimetric (TG) spectra of AlCl3, [Bmim]Cl, urea and their corresponding Lewis acidic ILs. The weight loss below 150 °C can be attributed to the loss of adsorbed water in ILs and AlCl3. When raising the temperature to 180 °C, the rate of weight loss of AlCl3 increases drastically owing to the sublimation of AlCl3. By comparison, when AlCl3 merges with [Bmim]Cl/urea to form Lewis acidic ILs, the decomposition rate of AlCl3 decreases significantly, suggesting that the interactions between AlCl3 and [Bmim]Cl/urea enhances the stability of AlCl3. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) analysis was conducted to identify the possible interaction of functional groups (Fig. 4b). For urea, the stretching frequency of N–H bond appears at 3450 cm−1. The characteristic peak at 1650 cm−1 is assigned to the C = O stretching frequency. The characteristic peak at 1450 cm−1 is ascribed to the stretching vibration of C-N bond. From FT-IR spectrum of urea/AlCl3, it can be seen that the stretching frequency of N–H bond slightly increases, while that of C = O and C-N bonds has a red shift. The blue shift of N–H bond may be ascribed that the chlorine atom in AlCl3 likely forms a hydrogen bond with N–H of urea, thus breaking the intermolecular hydrogen bond of urea itself. Meanwhile, the amide group of urea can also coordinate with AlCl3, which weakens the binding force of C = O and C-N bonds. For [Bmim]Cl, the characteristic peaks in the range between 3200 and 2800 cm−1 are assigned to the stretching vibrations of C–H bonds of alkyl groups and imidazole ring. The skeleton vibrations of C = C and C = N bonds of the imidazole ring appear at 1650–1400 cm−1. In the FT-IR spectrum of Lewis acidic IL [Bmim]Cl/AlCl3, these characteristic peaks are also observed but with a slight shift in the frequency and intensity. This phenomenon may be attributed to the electrostatic interaction between imidazolium cation and chloroaluminate anion. The interaction between Lewis acidic ILs and unsaturated ketone 1 was further probed by proton nuclear magnetic resonance (1H NMR) experiments (Fig. 4c and d). For [Bmim]Cl, the signal at 10.43 ppm is assigned to the proton characteristic peak of C2–H in imidazolium ring, while the chemical shifts of C4–H and C5–H appear at 7.44 and 7.60 ppm, respectively. By comparison, a mixture of [Bmim]Cl and AlCl3 leads to a decrease in the 1H chemical shift of imidazolium ring and some new signals beside the main proton peaks are observed. This phenomenon indicates that [Bmim]Cl likely reacts with AlCl3 to generate two new species (imidazolium chloroaluminates). Moreover, subjecting [Bmim]Cl/AlCl3 to compound 1 results in an increment in the 1H chemical shift of cyclohexane ring and 13C chemical shift of carbonyl group (201.83 to 216.98 ppm, Fig. S21 in Supporting Information), demonstrating that a coordination between ketone and Al3+ center is involved. Compared with the chemical shift of –NH2 in urea (Fig. 4d), this proton peak moves to lower field when combining urea and AlCl3, presumably owing to the de-shielding effect caused by coordination of Al3+ with amide group and hydrogen-bonding interaction of Cl− with –NH2. Analogously, for the mixture of urea/AlCl3 and compound 1, an increase of 1H chemical shift of cyclohexane ring and 13C chemical shift of carbonyl group (201.83 to 213.66 ppm, Fig. S22 in Supporting Information) is observed, reaffirming the existence of coordination between ketone and Al3+ center. 3.4 The mechanism for the formation of AlCl3-based ILs and catalytic spiro D-A reaction Based on these experimental results and the precedents on the chemistry of ILs [52], the mechanism for the formation of AlCl3-based ILs is outlined in Fig. 5 a. The separated chloride anion in [Bmim]Cl first reacts with Lewis acid AlCl3 to form [AlCl4]−, which can be balanced with positive [Bmim]+ via Coulombic interaction. It should be noted that when introducing excessive AlCl3, [AlCl4]− can further combine with another molecule of AlCl3 to generate [Al2Cl7]− species, which may serve as a counteranion as well. Therefore, the formation of [Bmim]+[AlCl4]− and [Bmim]+[Al2Cl7]− complexes can account for the appearance of new signals in 1H NMR spectrum of [Bmim]Cl/AlCl3. By contrast, the combination of urea with AlCl3 first gives rise to a positive species [AlCl2(urea)2]+ via loss of chloride anion. The resulting chloride anion then reacts with AlCl3 to deliver the counteranions [AlCl4]− or [Al2Cl7]−. Apart from strong Coulombic force, the coordination of Al3+ with C = N (imidazole ring)/C = O (urea) and hydrogen-bonding of Cl− with C2–H (imidazole ring)/–NH2 (urea) are involved as well. This fundamental interplay is the driving force for the formation of Lewis acidic ILs. With the catalysis of chloroaluminate ILs, the mechanism for spiro D-A reaction is proposed in Fig. 5b. Unsaturated ketone 1 is first activated by coordination of carbonyl group with chloroaluminate to generate Int-1. Subsequent nucleophilic 1,4-addition of Int-1 with isoprene results in the formation of relatively stable allylic cation intermediate Int-2. The nucleophilic enol motif further undergoes intramolecular attack at alkene terminus of allylic cation to furnish spiro D-A adduct 2 with the regeneration of chloroaluminate IL catalyst. Besides this stepwise [4 + 2] cyclization process, the activated intermediate Int-1 likely proceeds through a one-step concerted D-A cycloaddition with isoprene (Int-3) to afford product 2. 3.5 Catalytic hydrodeoxygenation of spiro D-A adduct over bifunctional catalyst Having established the efficient synthesis of spiro D-A adduct, additional efforts were devoted to its catalytic hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) towards polycyclic spiro-fuel. It is well-known that acidic catalysts are responsible for the deoxygenation and metal sites can promote the hydrogenation. Accordingly, for HDO reaction, a series of bifunctional catalysts consisting of acidic catalysts and hydrogenation metal catalysts were carefully scrutinized (Fig. 6 a and b). Over a physical mixture of acidic H-Beta/H-ZSM-5 and Pd/C at 160 °C, the target spiro-fuel 3 was indeed detected but with a low yield. Delightfully, the yield was improved to 91% when H-Y was used as co-catalyst. Other acids such as Al-MCM-41 and HPW (20 wt%) modified SiO2 gave decreased yields of spiro-fuel 3. With the aid of H-Y and Ru/C or Pt/C, moderate yields were obtained, while Rh/C showed a better catalytic performance. In the presence of non-noble catalysts such as Raney Cu and Raney Co, a sharp decrease in the efficiency was observed because of their moderate hydrogenation ability. It is noteworthy that Pd anchored on H-Y exhibited a high catalytic performance as well, demonstrating the synergistic role of metal and acidic support. Considering the simple operation procedure and relatively low price, a physical mixture of Pd/C and H-Y was chosen as the optimal catalyst. The temperature also exerted a significant impact on the transformation. As presented in Fig. 6c, the best result was achieved when HDO was conducted at 160 °C, while higher temperature resulted in carbon–carbon cleavage side reactions. More importantly, this heterogeneous catalyst mixture also exhibited good reusability for HDO reaction and no apparent decline in activity was observed after four runs (Fig. 6d). Thus, starting from renewable cyclohexanone and benzaldehyde, a three-step process including aldol condensation, D-A reaction and HDO were successfully developed, providing highly strained tricyclic C18 spiro-fuel in 78% overall yield. 3.6 Catalytic production of strained tricyclic C17 spiro-fuel with renewable cyclopentanone Given the fact that cyclopentanone can be largely prepared by one-step hydrogenation/rearrangement of renewable furfural [38,39], we further employed cyclopentanone as the feedstock to synthesize C17 spiro-fuel (Fig. 7 ). Following the same process, cyclopentanone and benzaldehyde underwent aldol condensation efficiently under basic conditions. With the aid of Lewis acidic urea/AlCl3 catalyst, the aldol product 4 easily coupled with isoprene, leading to the formation of spiro D-A adduct 5 in 92% yield. An eventual HDO over H-Y and Pd/C at 160 °C furnished the desired tricyclic spiro-fuel 6 (74% overall yield). 3.7 Comparison of the synthesized spiro polycyclic fuels and petroleum-based HED fuels The physical properties of as-prepared biofuels were further assessed. As illustrated in Table 2 , tricyclic C18 spiro-fuel 3 exhibited a high density of 0.943 g/mL, a low freezing point of −46 °C, and VNHOC of 42.3 MJ/L. Moreover, C17 spiro-fuel 6 had comparable properties as well (density: 0.932 g/mL; freezing point: −42 oC; VNHOC: 41.1 MJ/L). It can be seen that compared with petroleum-based HED fuel RJ-4 (density: 0.927 g/mL; freezing point: −40 oC; VNHOC: 39.0 MJ/L), our synthesized biofuels possessed higher energy densities, which was ascribed to the unique strained polycyclic spiro frameworks. Despite their high kinematic viscosity, the as-prepared renewable fuels can serve as promising additives to increase the energy density of traditional jet fuels. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, we have developed a sustainable route for the production of high-energy-density spirofuels with renewable cyclohexanone/cyclopentanone, benzaldehyde and isoprene as feedstocks. Benzaldehyde and cyclohexanone/cyclopentanone first underwent aldol condensation under basic conditions. The resulting products further reacted with isoprene to deliver spiro D-A adducts with the catalysis of Lewis acidic ILs under mild conditions. The benign urea/AlCl3 showed good catalytic performance and reusability for this step. A final HDO over H-Y and Pd/C gave the desired polycyclic spirofuels (78% and 74% overall yield). Besides, the combined catalyst also exhibited good stability during four runs of HDO reaction. The high strain and structural rigidity lead to high density (> 0.93 g/mL) and combustion heat (>41 MJ/L), as well as low freezing point (< −40 oC), which are better than the properties of widely used fuel RJ-4. Based on the good efficiency and energy properties, it is concluded that the renewable fuels produced in our work have the potential to replace traditional petroleum-derived HED fuels. This work not only expands new catalytic applications of Lewis acidic ILs, but also provides important insights into rational design of new strained spirofuels. coredata.dc:description: High-energy-density (HED) fuel (e.g. widely used JP-10 and RJ-4), featuring compact 3D polycyclic structure with high strain, is of critical importance for volume-limited military aircraft, since their high density and combustion heat can provide more propulsion energy. To reduce the reliance on petroleum source, it is highly desirable to develop renewable alternatives for the production of strained polycyclic HED fuel, but which remains a big challenge because of the inaccessibility caused by the high strain. We herein demonstrate a three-step catalytic route towards highly strained C17 and C18 spirofuel with biomass feedstocks. The process includes catalytic aldol condensation of renewable cyclohexanone/cyclopentanone with benzaldehyde, catalytic spiro Diels-Alder (D-A) reaction of aldol adduct with isoprene, and catalytic hydrodeoxygenation. The key spiro D-A reaction is enabled by the catalysis of heterogeneous Lewis acidic ionic liquid. The chloroaluminate IL, formed by benign urea and AlCl3, exhibits good catalytic performance and reusability for this step. An eventual hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) over Pd/C and H-Y produces strained tricyclic spirofuel with density >0.93 g/mL, combustion heat >41 MJ/L and freezing point < −40 °C, which are better than the properties of tactical fuel RJ-4. Therefore, it is anticipated that the as-prepared renewable fuels have the potential to replace traditional petroleum-derived HED fuels.
